items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Resolution #2014/2015-06 to Adopt Conflict of Interest Code and to Receive and Adopt Second Reading of Amended Board ByLaw 9270 Conflict of Interest and Revolving Door Restrictions
	 
	 
The Government Code and the Rules and Regulations adopted by the Fair Political Practices Commission require the District to designate positions which are required to submit disclosures of financial interests, and to update the titles of positions when new positions are created, when position titles are changed, or when positions or position duties are revised or modified to fall within the disclosure categories.  The changes reflected in the attached draft proposed revised Board ByLaw 9270, including Resolution #2014/2015-06 Adopting a Conflict of Interest Code and the Appendix include language that is in compliance with legal statutes and clarifies new positions to be included within the category of positions required to submit disclosures.  The District is required to submit the proposed approved changes to the Santa Clara County Counsel.
	 
	 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board receive and approve Resolution #2014/2015-06 to adopt the Conflict of Interest Code and receive and adopt the second reading of Board ByLaw 9270 Conflict of Interest and Revolving Door Restrictions and Appendix.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.01
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Strategic Plan Key Performance Measure Data Points
		 
The purpose of this report is to set benchmark data points for the Key Performance Measures (KPMs) as outlined in the East Side Union High School District Strategic Plan and to look at progress made over the last several years towards preparing all students for college and careers.  Student achievement data indicates that many students struggle to meet college and career readiness upon graduation from high school.  Furthermore, there are gaps between how well Asian students, Hispanic students, and African American students meet this goal.  In order to measure how well students graduating from the East Side Union High School District are prepared for our 21st century global economy, we have selected key data points which can be measured over time.
		 
Six years ago, prior to the Strategic Plan, the District began to look at the achievement gap among students and determine if the District had systems and policies in place that hindered closing this gap, as well as systems that would close the gap.  It was found that some course sequences created a fork in the pathway that led some to college preparedness and others simply to graduation.  It was left for students to choose whether or not to take a third year of math and science, again either leading to college preparedness or not.  Some students entering the District had access to summer programs that accelerated their math placement upon entering high school, advancing the road to college preparedness and college application distinction by completing calculus in high school.  Placement criteria into higher level course work was not the same at all 11 high schools, which disadvantaged some students. The District had many inequitable systems in place.
		 
The District began changing policies and implementing programs to even the playing field.  All core subject sequences have only one path and it leads to college preparedness.  Many schools began to place students by default into a third year of math or science.  In the 2010/11 school year, the Board of Trustees approved a default pathway for all students that leads to college and career readiness.  The first class to graduate having completed four years of high school under the default pathway is the class of 2015.  The District set consistent placement criteria into core courses for all schools.  Resources were prioritized to implement summer programs for all students that would advance or support higher level math placement in high school.  Grants were procured to implement programs at sites to support struggling students.  The data in this report will show that these system changes have shown improvement in preparing all students for college and careers, but that the District still has a long way to go to achieve this goal.  The Strategic Plan sets the course for further improvement.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the report as presented.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the report as presented.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item:  12.02
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Summer School 3-Year Trend
		 
East Side Union High School District has offered summer school programs to help students recover credits and to advance to higher level courses.  Before the economic downturn the District offered summer school programs at all of its comprehensive high schools.  Courses were offered as long as there were enough student requests and teachers willing to teach.  The state funded a small number of sections intended to help students accelerate as enrichment.  As the District began to experience budget constraints, the summer program was reduced by offering it at half the schools and alternating them every year.  Eventually the District had to reduce its summer program to the bare minimum required for Special Needs students.  Schools were left to use their site supplemental funds and outside grants to try to offer limited summer programs.  As the budget has begun to recover and additional supplemental funds have been available, the District has begun to once again offer summer programs at each of the high schools.  Beginning with the summer of 2013, we offered summer bridge (incoming freshman) programs at each of the high schools, and this past summer, we expanded to include some credit recovery offerings.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive the Third Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaints Quarterly Report for Period Covering July 1, 2014, through September 30, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
BACKGROUND
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case, which requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela / CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254), students in grades 10 to 12, inclusive, shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela / CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints, if any, filed from July 1, 2014, through September 30, 2014. 
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
The administration recommends that the Governing Board accept the Third Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2014, through September 30, 2014, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  12.05
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Associate Superintendent of Educational Services, and Jennifer Klassen, Coordinator of Student Services
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Agreement and Adopt Resolution #2014/2015-05 – Authorizing the Acceptance of Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Agreements with the City of San Jose from July 1, 2013, through September 30, 2016
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District will be providing representatives, Associate Principals of Administrative Services, Deans, and School-Community Specialists, to attend meetings and trainings, and to participate in the design and implementation of the Strategic Work Plan with members of the City of San Jose Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Technical Team.  East Side Union High School District will collaborate with other members of the Technical Team to the extent possible to meet the goals and carry out the necessary programs of the Work Plan.
	 
All members will comply with the confidentiality laws prescribed in Section 830.1 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code, which states that members of a juvenile justice multidisciplinary team engaged in the prevention, identification, and control of crime, including, but not limited to, criminal street gang activity, may disclose and exchange non-privileged information and writings to and with one another relating to any incidents of juvenile crime, including criminal street gang activity, that may also be part of a juvenile court record or otherwise designated as confidential under State law if the member of the team having that information or writing reasonably believes it is generally relevant to the prevention, identification, or control of juvenile crime or criminal street gang activity. Every member of a juvenile justice multidisciplinary team who receives such information or writings shall be under the same privacy and confidentiality obligations and subject to the same penalties for violating those obligations as the person disclosing or providing the information or writings. The team may include, but is not limited to, police officers or other law enforcement agents; prosecutors; probation officers; school district personnel or counseling personnel with juvenile crime or criminal street gang control experience or training; state, county, city, or special district recreation specialist with experience or training in juvenile crime or criminal street gang control.  The information obtained shall be maintained in a manner which ensures the protection of confidentiality.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Agreement and adopt Resolution #2014/2015-05 – Authorizing the Acceptance of Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Agreements with the City of San Jose from July 1, 2013, through September 30, 2016.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  13.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Karen Poon, Director of Finance, and Kelly Kwong, Senior Manager of Internal Controls
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Authorize Oak Grove High School Band Boosters, a School Connected Organization, to Solicit Contributions or Funds per Education Code 51520(a) and 51521
	 
	 
A School Connected Organization (“SCO”) is a separately organized and controlled non-profit entity that raises funds for student programs.  SCOs are frequently organized and known as “booster” clubs and parent/teacher/student associations.  SCO are not controlled by or overseen by the District.  The law requires, however, that SCO must obtain District approval to solicit funds on the District's school sites for the benefit of students, or if it solicits funds on the representation that the money received is to be used in whole or in part for the benefit of students or any other District school or students.
	 
Education Code section 51520(a) provides: 
“During school hours, and within one hour before the time of opening and within one hour after the time of closing of school, pupils of the public school shall not be solicited on school premises by teachers or others to subscribe or contribute to the funds of, to become members of, or to work for, any organization not directly under the control of the school authorities, unless the organization is a nonpartisan, charitable organization organized for charitable purposes by an act of Congress or under the laws of the state, the purpose of the solicitation is nonpartisan and charitable, and the solicitation has been approved by the county board of education or by the governing board of the school district in which the school is located.” (Emphasis added.)
	 
Education Code section 51521 further provides in part: 
“No person shall solicit any other person to contribute to any fund or to purchase any item of personal property, upon the representation that the money received is to be used wholly or in part for the benefit of any public school or the student body of any public school, unless such person obtains the prior written approval of either the governing board of the school district in which such solicitation is to be made or the governing board of the school district having jurisdiction over the school or student body represented to be benefited by such solicitation, or the designee of either of such boards.”
	 
In addition, Board Policy 1230 School Connected Organizations states, “Persons proposing to establish a school-connected organization shall submit a request to the Governing Board for authorization to operate at the school… Requests for subsequent authorization shall be presented to the Superintendent or designee annually…”
	 
After a review of the Oak Grove High School Band Boosters financials and other criteria, the Administration recommends that the Board authorize Oak Grove High School Band Boosters to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for the benefit of any District student with the condition that they must submit their financial statements and reconciled bank statements 30 days after each calendar quarter.  Approval to fundraise specifically does not include bingo.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Oak Grove High School Band Boosters, a School Connected Organization, pursuant to Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for nonpartisan and charitable purposes for the benefit of District students with the condition that they must submit their financial statements and reconciled bank statements 30 days after each calendar quarter.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Oak Grove High School Band Boosters, a School Connected Organization, pursuant to Education Code 51520(a) and 51521 to solicit contributions or funds on any District site for nonpartisan and charitable purposes for the benefit of District students with the condition that they must submit their financial statements and reconciled bank statements 30 days after each calendar quarter.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve Request for a One-Time Waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to Allow for a Fireworks Display at Mt. Pleasant High School on November 14, 2014
	 
	 
On behalf of:
- Emilio Gutierrez, ASB President
- Christian Montes, ASB Vice President
- Theresa Troung, ASB Secretary
- Isaiah Gonzales, ASB Treasurer
	 
The student's of Mt. Pleasant High School are requesting the use of fireworks/pyrotechnic display be approved on a one-time basis.  This display is for the homecoming game and the school's 50th anniversary celebration. 
	 
Board Policy 5142.1 prohibits the following at the sites and on District facilities: (1) open fires including Bon Fires of any type; (2) pyrotechnics of any type; and (3) explosive devices, such as firecrackers.  One-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 have been allowed for planned fireworks/pyrotechnics displays for special celebrations, such as, homecoming games or school anniversaries.
	 
Administration recommends Board approval of the one-time waiver on the following conditions:
This is a one-time waiver only.
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide copies of all necessary, required and appropriate governmental permits, licenses and approvals no later than one week before the planned event. 
The school and the fireworks and pyrotechnics company provider shall provide proof of adequate liability insurance coverage for the event  (including, but not limited to, an endorsement naming the District as a additional insured), to be determined by the Administration, to be provided at least one business day before the planned event. 
The fireworks/pyrotechnics displays shall be staged in a safe area.
The school shall obtain adequate security and public fire safety personnel and equipment on site during the scheduled event. 
No other fireworks of any kind shall be allowed on the school campus.
The pyrotechnic companies shall be responsible for any damage to the campus, including, but not limited to, the athletic and activities fields.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Associated Student Body (ASB) Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the request for a one-time waiver of Board Policy 5142.1 to allow for a fireworks display at Mt. Pleasant High School, subject to the conditions as presented and the approval from the San Jose Fire Marshall.

SUBJECT:
Ratify Staff Delegation to Make a Finding that the Independence High School Performing Arts Center - Building F Modernization Project is Substantially Complex and is Subject to Ten Percent (10%) Retention
	 
	 
On September 20, 2012, (Item 9.06) the Board of Trustees adopted Resolution # 2012/2013-03, establishing the criteria to be used in determining whether a project is substantially complex and thereby justifying a retention higher than five percent (5%), and delegated the authority to make such findings to the Superintendent, the Associated Superintendent of Business Services and the Superintendent’s designee as appropriate, but subject to ratification by the Board (Attachment A).
	 
Staff cited in the contract documents that the Independence High School Performing Arts Center - Building F Modernization Project is substantially complex and finds that the retention shall be ten percent (10%).
	 
The criteria in making this determination is that the project is subject to higher safety standards than other public works projects; is subject to design approval by the State of California Division of State Architect; the project involves unique scheduling or sequencing or other critical path methods; utilizing lease leaseback alternative delivery method, and the project will have specialized systems and/or safety measures included in its design to protect District students, teachers, staff and/or visitors.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the staff's finding that the Independence High School Performing Arts Center - Building F Modernization Project is substantially complex and is subject to ten percent (10%) retention.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of September, 2014
							 
							 
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of September, 2014, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment of Goods and Services adopted in May, 2009.  The Policy states that, "The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting."  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval on issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the "transparency" of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Associate Superintendent of Human Resources
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive Certificated Class Size Report - Compliance with 10/08/04 Stipulated Arbitrator's Award
	 
	 
On October 8, 2004, the District and the East Side Teachers Association were parties to a settlement agreement under the authority of Arbitrator Barbara Bridgewater.  In Section II, #16 of the Consent Award, the District agreed to provide a report to the Board of Trustees and to the Association President regarding the degree to which each comprehensive high school met its responsibilities under Article 15 of the Collective Bargaining Agreement.  This report is based on day seventeen (17) of school, and includes for each school:
	 
The percentage of successful student placement on the last Infinite Campus [Student Information System] master schedule run
The total number of classes over Article 15 limits not exempted by Article 15.8 limits
The total number of students with incomplete schedules
The number of students upon which staffing projections were made and the actual number students enrolled
The changes to sites' certificated FTE allocation since the first day of school
The number of students that have had class changes since the first day of school
This report contains data retrieved from the school sites, Information Technology, and Business Services.  This report is provided to keep the Board informed regarding Certificated Class Size status.
